articles.headline: ‘Mexico First’ Campaign Could End Welcome for U.S. Oil Giants
articles.snippet: The leading presidential candidate has vowed to reverse energy policies that have attracted foreign drillers and helped absorb a natural-gas glut.
articles.abstract: The leading presidential candidate has vowed to reverse energy policies that have attracted foreign drillers and helped absorb a natural-gas glut.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As President Trump moves to recast trade and border relations with Mexico, American oil companies are worried that the prospective winner of Mexico’s presidential election will play his own nationalist card.

articles.headline: Korea Talks Begin as Kim Jong-un Crosses to South’s Side of DMZ
articles.snippet: A meeting between Mr. Kim, North Korea’s leader, and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea seemed unthinkable just a few months ago.
articles.abstract: A meeting between Mr. Kim, North Korea’s leader, and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea seemed unthinkable just a few months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un on Friday became the first North Korean leader to set foot in South Korean-controlled territory, starting a historic summit meeting with the South’s president that will test Mr. Kim’s willingness to bargain away his nuclear weapons.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: $11 Million a Year for a Law Partner? Bidding War Grows at Top-Tier Firms
articles.snippet: For years, partners rarely left the firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. But recent defections to Kirkland & Ellis have pointed to new forces at work.
articles.abstract: For years, partners rarely left the firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. But recent defections to Kirkland & Ellis have pointed to new forces at work.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when many law firm partnerships are revolving doors, the move by several partners from one large firm to another would hardly merit headlines.

articles.headline: For Many, Life in Trump’s Orbit Ends in a Crash Landing
articles.snippet: Proximity to President Trump has been a crushing experience for many who arrived with stellar careers and independent reputations yet ended up losing so much.
articles.abstract: Proximity to President Trump has been a crushing experience for many who arrived with stellar careers and independent reputations yet ended up losing so much.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Another day, another casualty. Or two.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: North and South Korea Set Bold Goals: A Final Peace and No Nuclear Arms
articles.snippet: Kim Jong-un of North Korea and Moon Jae-in of the South agreed to work to formally end the Korean War and rid the peninsula of nuclear weapons.
articles.abstract: Kim Jong-un of North Korea and Moon Jae-in of the South agreed to work to formally end the Korean War and rid the peninsula of nuclear weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The leaders of North and South Korea agreed on Friday to work to remove all nuclear weapons from the Korean Peninsula and, within the year, pursue talks with the United States to declare an official end to the Korean War, which ravaged the peninsula from 1950 to 1953.

articles.headline: A Spy’s Tale: The TV Prankster Who Says He Became a Double Agent
articles.snippet: Robert Moore posed as a documentary filmmaker to monitor activists for a K2 Intelligence client. He contends he switched sides. Now he’s being sued. His unusual case offers a peek into a growing industry.
articles.abstract: Robert Moore posed as a documentary filmmaker to monitor activists for a K2 Intelligence client. He contends he switched sides. Now he’s being sued. His unusual case offers a peek into a growing industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A former television producer here, Robert Moore, once loved working on comedies akin to “Candid Camera” or “Da Ali G Show” that conned the unsuspecting.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew by 2.3% in First Quarter, Easing Slightly
articles.snippet: The figure falls short of President Trump’s goal of at least 3 percent. But most forecasters expect a stronger pace for the rest of the year.
articles.abstract: The figure falls short of President Trump’s goal of at least 3 percent. But most forecasters expect a stronger pace for the rest of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy grew at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in the first quarter, the government reported Friday, offering a preliminary glance at how last year’s sweeping package of tax cuts is affecting consumers and businesses this year.

articles.headline: Can San Diego Ditch the Power Company? Not Without a Fight
articles.snippet: San Diego may join a growing trend and become a retailer of electricity, seeking better rates than the local utility and pursuing clean-energy goals.
articles.abstract: San Diego may join a growing trend and become a retailer of electricity, seeking better rates than the local utility and pursuing clean-energy goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Seeking control over the way their electricity was generated and paid for, Cape Cod residents banded together two decades ago to bypass the local utility and buy power in bulk.
